Journal.Title: The journal of physical chemistry. A

Article.ArticleTitle: Temperature and Isotope Dependent Kinetics of Nickel-Catalyzed Oxidation of Methane by Ozone.

AbstractText: The temperature dependent kinetics of Ni<sup>+</sup> + O<sub>3</sub> and of NiO<sup>+</sup> + CH<sub>4</sub>/CD<sub>4</sub> are measured from 300 to 600 K using a selected-ion flow tube apparatus. Together, these reactions comprise a catalytic cycle converting CH<sub>4</sub> to CH<sub>3</sub>OH. The reaction of Ni<sup>+</sup> + O<sub>3</sub> proceeds at the collisional limit, faster than previously reported at 300 K. The NiO<sup>+</sup> product reacts further with O<sub>3</sub>, also at the collisional limit, yielding both higher oxides (up to NiO<sub>5</sub><sup>+</sup> is observed) as well as undergoing an apparent reduction back to Ni<sup>+</sup>. This apparent reduction channel is due to the oxidation channel yielding NiO<sub>2</sub><sup>+</sup>* with sufficient energy to dissociate. <sup>4</sup>NiO<sup>+</sup> + CH<sub>4</sub> (CD<sub>4</sub>) (whereas <sup>4</sup>NiO<sup>+</sup> refers to the quartet state of NiO<sup>+</sup>) proceeds with a rate constant of (2.6 ± 0.4) × 10<sup>-10</sup> cm<sup>3</sup> s<sup>-1</sup> [(1.8 ± 0.5) × 10<sup>-10</sup> cm<sup>3</sup> s<sup>-1</sup>] at 300 K and a temperature dependence of ∼ T<sup>-0.7±0.3</sup> (∼ T<sup>-1.1±0.4</sup>), producing only the <sup>2</sup>Ni<sup>+</sup> + <sup>1</sup>CH<sub>3</sub>OH channel up to 600 K. Statistical modeling of the reaction based on calculated stationary points along the reaction coordinate reproduces the experimental rate constant as a function of temperature but underpredicts the kinetic isotope shift. The modeling was found to better represent the data when the crossing from quartet to doublet surface was incomplete, suggesting a possible kinetic effect in crossing from quartet to doublet surfaces. Additionally, the modeling predicts a competing <sup>3</sup>NiOH<sup>+</sup> + <sup>2</sup>CH<sub>3</sub> channel to become increasingly important at higher temperatures.
